Award.AwardTitle: Integrated Photothermal Platform for Delivering Infectious Bacteria into Mammalian Cells in BSL 3 Environment for High Throughput Screening

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1404080
Chiou, Pei-Yu
Title: Integrated Photothermal Platform for Delivering Infectious Bacteria into Mammalian Cells in BSL 3 Environment for High Throughput Screening

Significance:
A major obstacle in cell biology and microbial pathogenesis research is the absence of any method for efficient high-throughput delivery of micron-sized cargo directly into the cytosol of cells. This proposal aims to develop a compact platform that will overcome this obstacle. We have devised a novel strategy that uses a laser to create micron-sized bubbles that transiently disrupt the cell membrane and drive bacteria-sized cargo into the cell cytosol. A unique advantage of our proposed platform is that its compact size will allow it to fit in a biosafety cabinet, thus enabling work with highly infectious bacteria that could not be studied safely with any currently available delivery method. In addition to bacteria, our platform will also be able to deliver directly into the cell cytosol subcellular organelles such as mitochondria, chromosomes, and micron sized "nano-machines". Success of our project will enable researchers to ask experimental questions that hitherto could not be answered and to make advances in diverse fields, including microbial pathogenesis, cell biology, cell engineering, and regenerative medicine.

Technical Description:
This platform is realized by a silicon chip-based massively parallel photothermal nanoblade fabricated by micromachining. A nanoblade chip is seeded with the host cells, and the bacteria that will be injected are loaded in a custom-built fluid chamber. A handheld size fiber laser coupled with a custom built optical scanner to provide cavitation excitation over a large area. Immediately after laser pulsing, pressure driven flows will be triggered to actively drive micron-sized bacteria into cell cytosol. Massively parallel delivery into 100,000 cells takes only 10 seconds, which is 5 orders of magnitude faster than the current pipette based delivery approaches. To accomplish our goal, we plan to conduct the following projects. Project 1 is to develop a compact photothermal platform for high-throughput delivery of infectious samples in BSL 3 environment. Project 2 is to develop an all-optical driven nanoblade platform for ultrahigh throughput large cargo delivery and project 3 is to demonstrate the utility of massively parallel photothermal nanoblade in high-throughput screening to identify bacterial genes required for cytosolic growth and host cell pathways that restrict bacterial cytosolic growth.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims to develop high throughput intracellular delivery platforms capable of introducing bacteria and other large size cargo  into cell cytosol in BSL 3 environment. During the course of the funding period, our team with expertise in engineering and biology has achieved several major technical accomplishments, trained phd students, and provided research opportunities to undergraduate and underrepresented students.

We have successfully demonstrated a platform called BLAST for high efficiency, high throughput delivery of large sized cargo into mammalian cells with light pulses. BLAST is a platform capable of delivering large sized cargo up to micron size into ~100,000 cells in minutes with high transfection efficiency and high cell viability. BLAST overcomes the major technical barriers of prior delivery approaches that are not able to effectively delivering large cargo into cells. With the BLAST platform, we were able to successfully deliver live bacteria, proteins, enzymes, and various types of artificial nanoparticles into cell cytosol bypassing endocytosis.

We have also utilized the photothermal nanoblade technology to demonstrate the first mitochondria transfer to restore metabolite profile in mammalian cells. mtDNA sequence alterations are challenging to generate but desirable for basic studies and potential correction of mtDNA diseases. Unlike the nuclear genome, strategies for altering mtDNA are limited. Under the support of this grant, we have reported a new method for transferring isolated mitochondria into somatic mammalian cells using a photothermal nanoblade, which bypasses endocytosis and cell fusion. The nanoblade rescued the pyrimidine auxotroph phenotype and respiration of ρ0 cells that lack mtDNA.

The ultimate goal of this grant is the development of a fully optically powered photothermal platform for intracellular delivery without the need of any external pumps. This will allow this platform to be fully compatible with standard 96 wells, or large array, for high throughput combinatorial delivery for large-scale screening in BSL 3 facilities. This goal has been accomplished by a recently developed platform called VOCANO (Vertical Optically-driven Cavity-assisted Nuclear Opening).
